Hello SciShow, I love the work you guys do in science education, especially the way you guys take very complex topics and present them in a manner that is easy to understand for anyone and everyone. There are some minor inaccuracies in this video that I noticed and wanted to point out. I used to work as a telemetry technician within the medical field for a living, which meant continuously reading different patients' EKGs for 12 hours at a time. At 2:12 in this video, you guys present different rhythms a patient's heart could be in. The rhythm you guys have labeled as "normal heartbeat" isn't actually normal. If I remember correctly, it looks like a sinus rhythm with a second-degree type 2 heart block and a bundle branch block. Notice how there are two little waves in that rhythm before a big triangle-looking wave. Both of those little waves are called p-waves, while the big triangle looking wave is called a QRS complex. The medium-sized wave following the QRS complex is called a T-wave. In a normal rhythm, aka normal sinus rhythm, there should only be a one to one to one ratio of the p-wave, QRS complex, and t-wave, which represents a single heartbeat. But since there are two p-waves for each heartbeat, that means the patient has a second-degree type 2 heart block. The QRS complex is also larger than normal, indicating a bundle branch block. Either way, I still love the work you guys do, and will continue to recommend you guys to my family and friends when to comes science.

I had a heart attack a couple months ago. Known as the Widow Maker and had a 100% occlusion of the LAD. They cathed, angioplasty and stented the occlusion which relieved the chest pain. I'm also the 18th person in the world to get the TherOx treatment. Created by an Oakwood hospital cardiologist in Dearborn, Michigan. It's when they give pressurized concentrated oxygen via the heart cath for an hour after the stent. It reduces complications from the heart attack 3-5 months and 3-5 years later. It's being released worldwide as the gold standard treatment for heart attacks with hopes of using it in stroke victims in a few years.

Despite the advances in the science of heart attacks, many women still die from heart attacks because their symptoms are different from men's symptoms. The meds for heart disease are usually made for men, while women are atypical. This is significant and scary for women with heart disease.

Before 1970, doctors in Los Angeles found that if a heart attack victim got medical help within an hour, they had the best chance of survival. From this, Los Angeles created its first paramedic program. So did Louisville, KY.

Yes, studies have shown in the 1970's that fatty plaques have caused heart attacks, and that was also the age of defibrillators. Even if we really didn't quite know what caused them, heart attacks were treated immediately and well, saving many lives of people who would have come to the hospital dead on arrival.

Personally, I'm grateful to have lived through this period and into the age of cholesterol awareness, blood thinners, stents, and clot-busters. It makes me appreciate all of the tech we've developed.

That claim about the 80s is definitely wrong. We had a family remember die from heart attack in 1952, and we all knew it was because he had too many carbs and oil. In the 1960's, fear of oil and cholesterol was at an absolute all-time high, we all knew it blocked your arteries and gave you a heart attack.

Maybe you could say, in the 80s was when "definitive proof was made". But the fact that the plaque got smaller after a heart attack doesn't prove at all that the plaque didn't happen after the heart attack, so the proposed proof in the video wasn't really a valid proof at all. A real proof would be to show that the patient had the plaque before the heart attack happened, and then get smaller _after_.

For a follow-up, I suggest looking at sex/gender differences - most women who have heart attacks don't actually have obstructive blocks from plaque as the cause! Do a google of INOCA and MINOCA! :) Microvascular disease is underrecognized. Also different risk factors/different effects between the sexes!

I had a heart attack.  My main complaint when they did the first heart cath was, "I want to see!"  They did show me after.  The 2nd heart cath I had was several years later.  They asked me if I had anyone with me, to which I replied "No."  I asked them why they did not want to do it, and they said they would have to give me a sedative.  I told them to forget the sedative and just do it.  The cardiologist said I was the only patient he ever did that with that had no sedative.  The only complaint I had was the same as the first time.  I wanted to see.  I did have a local anesthetic to prevent pain at the site they were working, it was on my wrist.  The first time was on the inside of my thigh.  When he finished with me, I could see my blood had sprayed all over the lights, and ceiling above his head.  Also, on his scrubs and safety glasses.  Still, I was able to call a taxi to take me home after.

I've had "high cholesterol" for 20+ years and my new cardiologist wanted to put me on a statin. I asked what the threshold of plaque was to indicate treatment and she said "A CAC (Coronary Artery Calcium) score over 300. Over 100 and it's time to be concerned. Under 100 and you're not at risk." So I got my CT CAC score done. My result was 6.1

Yeah, so no statin for me.

Why? I've been on a low-carb no -added sugar diet for 4+ years due to a pre-diabetes diagnosis. I went on the diet, still am, eat one meal a day. No carbs for the most part (I'm no angel but it's not often). My fasting A1C is still in the normal range and I'm very active.

So what might be interesting is looking at heart disease across cultures and diet.

Why didn't you mention Troponin levels? The chemical that the heart releases when it's being damaged or dying. That's the way they diagnosed my heart attack last year. My EKG showed no signs of an attack.

Heart attacks are the leading cause of mortality globally, and have been so for much of human history. It is hard to know exactly what causes them. The electrocardiogram, often known as the ECG or EKG, was invented and used in the early 1900s, which was a significant advancement. In the 1980s, scientists were able to use X-rays to examine the hearts of over 300 survivors of heart attacks and discover that they could withstand certain obstructions over time. After decades of research, doctors have finally conclusively identified what causes heart attacks: they are caused by clots forming in the arteries supplying oxygen and nutrients to the heart. If the arteries are blocked, or if a blood clot develops and becomes caught in an artery, the heart's muscle cells are starved and begin to die, resulting in a heart attack.

Heart attacks are the no.1 cause of death worldwide, but that doesn't mean everyone everywhere is most likely to die of a heart attack. For example, the no.1 cause of death for minors in the U.S. is gun violence. Just a reminder of how to read generalised stats
